effect.translation[0].definitions[0].def: a change that is caused by an event, action etc
effect.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: This ingredient also has the effect of making your skin look younger.
A system failure has a knock-on effect throughout the whole hotel.
the cumulative effect of human activities on the global environment
A much lower dose of the painkiller can still produce the desired effect.
In mental illness, there is a complex relationship between cause and effect.
My parents’ divorce had a big effect on me.
the harmful effects of modern farming practices
the long-term effects of the drug
I could feel the effects of the thin mountain air.
effect.translation[0].definitions[1].def: if a law, rule, or system takes effect or comes into effect, it officially starts
effect.translation[0].definitions[2].def: if a law, rule, or system is in effect, it is being used now
effect.translation[0].definitions[3].def: an idea or feeling that an artist, speaker, book etc tries to make you think of or to feel
effect.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: Turner’s paintings give an effect of light.
effect.translation[0].definitions[4].def: an unusual or impressive sound or image that is artificially produced for a film, play, or radio programme
effect.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: have an effect on something/somebody
Eating junk food will eventually have an effect on your health.
have the effect of doing something
The news had the effect of making everyone feel better.
produce an effect
If we combine these sounds, they produce an effect that is almost jazzy.
feel an effect
Small companies will feel the effect of the recession first.
lessen/reduce an effect
The government must take action to reduce the effects of pollution.
cushion the effect of something
Lower mortgage rates will cushion the effect of rising house prices.
an effect lasts
The effect of the drug lasts about six hours.
an effect wears off
The effect of the anaesthetic was beginning to wear off.
big/major
The teachers’ strike had a big effect on many schools.
significant/substantial/marked
Global warming could have a significant effect on agriculture in many parts of the world.
profound/powerful
My father’s death had a profound effect on me.
dramatic
Taking the new drug had a dramatic effect on his health.
The drugs have a relatively small effect on a lot of patients.
negligible/minimal
The advertising campaign had a negligible effect on demand.
immediate
The announcement had an immediate effect on stock prices.
Inflation can sometimes have some good effects on the economy.
positive/beneficial
The incident had a very positive effect on his career.
Working too hard was beginning to have a bad effect on my health.
negative/detrimental
the negative effects of low rainfall
harmful/damaging
the harmful effects of drinking too much alcohol
Some of the effects can be quite damaging.
visible/noticeable
He drank five beers, but they did not seem to have any visible effect on him.
the adverse effects
No one told them about the adverse effects of smoking marijuana.
the long-term/short-term effect
Many boxers suffer with the long-term effects of punches to the head.
a knock-on effect
The strike could have a knock-on effect at other airports.
a cumulative effect
The cumulative effect of these policies will be to push up inflation.
the desired effect
His team talk had the desired effect because the team went on to win the game.
the full effect
We won’t know the full effect of the tax changes until the end of the financial year.
a calming/soothing effect
His words seemed to have a calming effect on the crowd.
effect.translation[0].note_box[1].sectio: effect
a change that is caused by an event, action etc
The people in this area are still suffering from the effects of the famine.
The treatment had little or no effect.
impact
an effect that happens as a result of something important, especially a big and permanent effect
Changes in technology have had a massive impact on the way we work.
the environmental impact of industrial activity
influence
the effect that something has on people’s opinions or behaviour, or on how something develops
American television has had a big influence on popular culture in the west.
His ideas had a lot of influence at the time.
side effect
an unwanted and unplanned effect that something has – used especially about drugs and medical treatment
Common side effects of the drug may include headaches and muscle pains.
after-effects
bad effects that continue for a long time after the thing that caused them
A traumatic experience can have severe psychological after-effects.
the after-effects of the war
repercussions
the effects that happen later as a result of an event or decision, especially a range of effects that continue for a long time
The scandal could have serious repercussions for her career.
The judge’s decision is likely to have important repercussions for future cases of this kind.
a knock-on effect
used when something has an effect on something, which then has an effect on something else
Higher oil prices have a knock-on effect on other fuels.
footprint
the effect that human activities have on the environment, caused by using up its natural resources, pollution, waste etc
Businesses all over the world must attempt to reduce their environmental footprint.
The house has a low carbon footprint (=it uses very little energy from carbon and therefore is good for the environment).
effect.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: Many parents lack confidence in their ability to effect change in their children’s behaviour.
effect.translation[2].definitions[0].def: the way in which an action, event, or person changes someone or something
effect.translation[2].definitions[0].exa: Inflation is having a disastrous effect on the economy.
effect.translation[2].definitions[1].def: to make a plan or idea happen
effect.translation[2].definitions[1].exa: It won’t be easy to put the changes into effect.
effect.translation[2].definitions[2].def: if a new arrangement, law, system etc comes into effect or takes effect, it officially starts
effect.translation[2].definitions[2].exa: The new tax rates come into effect in April.
effect.translation[2].definitions[3].def: starting to happen immediately, or from a particular date
effect.translation[2].definitions[3].exa: Mr Hoskins is appointed manager, with immediate effect.
effect.translation[2].definitions[4].exa: Insurance also covers personal effects required during travel on company business.
effect.translation[3].definitions[0].exa: You must obtain your client’s approval of the estate agent’s fees before you effect payment of them.
